directorQuestion: Is this one team’s problem (process) or multiple teams’ problem (platform/architecture)?

steps.label: Code Review Turnaround
steps.reason: Often 40–60% of Lead Time. Check if reviews are the bottleneck. Check AI PR size (6.2) for inflated review load.

steps.label: Build & CI Cycle Time
steps.reason: Slow tests, flaky reruns, or resource contention in CI.

steps.label: Blocked Work Rate + Cross-Team Dependencies
steps.reason: Architectural coupling causing wait states. High cross-team dependency count signals organizational bottleneck.

directorQuestion: Is quality declining because of testing gaps (invest in testing) or because people are overloaded (invest in capacity)?

steps.label: Test Coverage on Changed Paths
steps.reason: New code without tests. Check if changed code paths have adequate coverage. Check AI PR quality delta (AI-2) for AI-specific quality issues.

steps.label: Escaped Defect Rate
steps.reason: What’s getting through? Identifies where testing and review gaps exist.

steps.label: Toil % + On-Call Burden
steps.reason: Overloaded engineers rushing. High toil and on-call burden leave less time for careful work.

directorQuestion: Are we having new types of failures (architecture) or repeating old ones (follow-through failure)?

steps.label: Incident Rate by Severity
steps.reason: More incidents or bigger incidents? Identify which services are consuming the most budget.

steps.label: MTTR (Mean Time to Restore)
steps.reason: Are incidents taking longer to resolve? Slow recovery amplifies budget consumption.

steps.label: Post-Incident Action Item Completion
steps.reason: Are we fixing root causes? Unfinished action items from previous incidents cause repeat failures.

directorQuestion: Is this a capacity/architecture problem (invest) or a process/discipline problem (coach)?

steps.label: Error Budget Burn Rate
steps.reason: Gradual erosion or sudden breach? Determines if this is chronic degradation or acute incident.

steps.label: Deployment Frequency + CFR
steps.reason: Shipping too aggressively? High deploy rate with rising CFR means releases are destabilizing services.

steps.label: MTTR + Rollback Rate
steps.reason: Slow to recover when things break? If rollbacks are frequent or recovery is slow, the deploy pipeline needs investment.

directorQuestion: Is this a tooling problem (platform investment) or a workload problem (capacity/scope)?

steps.label: Toil %
steps.reason: Increasing manual work. High toil directly erodes developer satisfaction and productivity.

steps.label: CI Cycle Time + Flaky Test Rate + Cognitive Load
steps.reason: Frustrating build experience. Slow CI, unreliable test results, and AI-induced cognitive overhead are top developer complaints.

steps.label: On-Call Burden + Context Switching + Burnout
steps.reason: Operational overload. Excessive on-call, fragmented attention, and burnout risk destroy focus and satisfaction.

directorQuestion: Is this a specific team/manager problem or an org-wide systemic issue?

steps.label: Attrition Pattern Analysis
steps.reason: Themes from exit interviews — growth? comp? management? burnout? Classify departures to target interventions.

steps.label: DX Score + eNPS
steps.reason: Was this predicted by leading indicators? Low DX and eNPS often precede attrition by 6–12 months.

steps.label: Span of Control + Burnout Risk
steps.reason: Managers stretched too thin for coaching? High span of control and burnout risk correlate with disengagement and attrition.

directorQuestion: Are we bad at planning (estimation) or bad at protecting capacity (interrupts)?

steps.label: WIP (Work in Progress)
steps.reason: Too much parallel work. High WIP means too much started, too little finished, and context switching overhead.

steps.label: Blocked Work Rate
steps.reason: External dependencies blocking planned work. Blocked items cause missed commitments outside team control.

steps.label: Incident Rate
steps.reason: Firefighting consuming planned capacity. Unplanned incident work steals sprint time.

directorQuestion: Are OKRs failing because they’re bad OKRs (alignment) or because we can’t execute (delivery)?

steps.label: Sprint Commitment Accuracy
steps.reason: Can’t deliver committed work. If sprints aren’t met, quarterly OKRs won’t be either.

steps.label: Investment Mix
steps.reason: Too much “run the business” work. If KTLO and unplanned work dominate, strategic initiatives starve.

steps.label: Cross-Team Dependencies
steps.reason: Blocked by other teams. High dependency count signals that OKR achievement requires cross-team coordination that isn’t happening.

directorQuestion: Is this a resource management problem (FinOps) or an architecture problem (engineering investment)?

steps.label: Infrastructure Utilization
steps.reason: Over-provisioning. Check if resources are allocated but underused.

steps.label: Delivery Bottleneck Analysis
steps.reason: Decompose Lead Time by stage to identify if architecture inefficiency (N+1 queries, missing caching, slow builds) is causing cost increases through delivery slowdowns.

steps.label: Tech Debt Ratio
steps.reason: Accumulated architectural debt causing expensive workarounds and inefficient resource usage.

triggerCondition: AI adoption but no delivery improvement
directorQuestion: Are we missing AI prerequisites (platform, small batches, testing) or is AI genuinely not suited to this codebase?

steps.label: AI Trust Score
steps.reason: Engineers don’t trust AI output — cognitive overhead eroding gains.

steps.label: Verification Overhead Ratio
steps.reason: Review time exploding — AI creating net-negative flow impact.

steps.label: AI PR Quality Delta + Readiness Score
steps.reason: Quality declining or prerequisites (platform, version control, small batches) missing.

triggerCondition: Deployment Frequency drops >50% without reliability event
directorQuestion: Is this a process overhead problem (approvals, CABs) or a capacity problem (team shrinkage, competing priorities)?

steps.label: Review Process Overhead
steps.reason: Check if approval processes or review bottlenecks are stalling deployments. AI-inflated PR sizes may be overwhelming reviewers.

steps.label: Team Capacity & Interrupts
steps.reason: Check if blocked work, on-call burden, or unplanned interrupts are consuming deployment capacity.

steps.label: Post-Incident Risk Aversion
steps.reason: After major incidents, teams often over-correct with excessive gates. Check if CFR fear is creating deployment paralysis.

directorQuestion: Is this an architectural coupling problem (invest in decoupling) or a communication problem (invest in processes)?

steps.label: Blocked Work Rate
steps.reason: Rising blocked work confirms dependency bottlenecks. Identify which teams are most frequently blocked and by whom.

steps.label: Knowledge Concentration + Span of Control
steps.reason: High dependency count with narrow span of control suggests knowledge silos. Check if key individuals are bottlenecks.

steps.label: Communication Patterns
steps.reason: Rising meeting load with declining DX suggests coordination overhead is crushing productivity. Consider architectural decoupling.

directorQuestion: Is this an environment/tooling problem (platform investment) or a knowledge transfer problem (mentoring/documentation)?

steps.label: Environment Setup Time
steps.reason: If setup takes >1 day, the onboarding bottleneck starts before any code is written. Check IDP maturity.

steps.label: Mentor Availability
steps.reason: High toil and on-call burden on senior engineers means no capacity for mentoring. New hires are left to figure things out alone.

steps.label: Documentation & Tooling Currency
steps.reason: High cognitive load for new hires suggests documentation gaps or outdated tooling. Check IDP adoption as a proxy for self-service capability.

directorQuestion: Is unplanned work growing (reactive problem) or is feature demand crowding out platform investment (prioritization problem)?

steps.label: Toil % + Incident Rate
steps.reason: Rising toil consuming discretionary capacity. High incident rate forces reactive work that crowds out planned investments.

steps.label: Tech Debt Ratio + Debt Age
steps.reason: Accumulated debt forcing reactive maintenance. Old unresolved debt compounds into unplanned work as workarounds fail.

steps.label: Blocked Work + Cross-Team Dependencies
steps.reason: Cross-team dependencies creating unplanned coordination overhead. High blocked rate signals capacity lost to waiting, not building.

triggerCondition: Declining % of work with measurable business impact
directorQuestion: Are we measuring the wrong things (attribution methodology) or building the wrong things (prioritization)?

steps.label: OKR Achievement Rate
steps.reason: If OKRs are hit but not attributed, the problem is measurement methodology â€” work is delivering value but tracking can't prove it.

steps.label: Investment Mix + Tech Debt Age
steps.reason: If feature allocation is low, capacity is going to non-attributable work like maintenance and debt remediation.

steps.label: Sprint Commitment + Blocked Work
steps.reason: If commitments are missed, planned attributable work isn't completing. Blocked work may indicate that attributable features are stuck in dependency queues.
